Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genetic Architecture of a Chromosomal Inversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chromosomal inversions, or structurally reversed portions of a chromosome, are a common and enigmatic form of genome structure evolution. Because inversions can suppress recombination between many genes, they are often characterized as 'supergenes' and have the potential to influence evolution in distinct ways from mutations in single genes. This project aims to dissect the evolution of one recently formed inversion in Drosophila melanogaster by identifying the genes that the inversion has captured. To accomplish this, the researchers will employ genetic mapping techniques using strains that do not bear the inversion, but that display a similar phenotype as inversion-bearing strains. After identifying the relevant genes, the researchers will use publically available data to analyze these genes to understand both their short and long term evolution.

Beyond the direct scientific advances of this project, the broader impacts of the proposed research are numerous. The human genome is known to be highly polymorphic for chromosomal inversions and inversions have been directly implicated in human health concerns including reduced fertility and numerous diseases. It follows that understanding the natural selection that affects inversion evolution may yield valuable insight into many common human diseases. This project includes numerous opportunities for both undergraduate and high school students to participate, and the researchers are actively recruiting additional students to assist with this project and develop their own related projects. Finally, the software and theoretical tools developed for this project will enable other researchers to conduct similar research on chromosomal inversions in many other species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project aimed to understand the genetic basis of natural selection acting on chromosomal inversions—reversals in the linear order or a region of a chromosome. Inversions are widespread across taxa, contribute to adaptive phenotypes, and are associated with many diseases in humans, hence exploring the evolutionary forces that affect inversions can yield valuable insights into a wide variety of processes. In this project, we study inversions in the genetic model species Drosophila melanogaster. From the outset, we began with two central goals, both of which have been successfully addressed during the course of this research program, and will be published in peer-reviewed journals soon. 

First, we aimed to develop a computer simulation program that could accommodate the unique effects of chromosomal inversions, and therefore could simulate the evolution of these large structural rearrangements within large populations. We successfully used this code to develop novel theory to examine how natural selection on many separate mutations can affect the evolutionary trajectories of inversions. We then showed that this theory could account for many empirical observations about the evolution of chromosomal inversions. The outcomes of this project are described in our manuscript, which is currently under review at the journal Genetics. Importantly, two undergraduate students contributed substantively to this research program, and they are both included as authors on this manuscript. The code for this program is available to the broader research community as a supplemental file with the manuscript, and will be useful to a variety of other researchers studying chromosomal inversions in other systems. Furthermore, we are currently producing a detailed user manual that will enable other researchers to use and apply our code for their purposes.

The second goal of this project was to study empirical patterns of genetic and phenotypic variation associated with chromosomal inversions. Towards this, we have compiled and studied a large dataset of genetic variation data for individuals containing known chromosomal inversion and individuals who do not. By contrasting patterns of genetic variation between arrangements, we are able to identify genetic targets of natural selection. We are using the computer simulation framework described above to ask how strongly natural selection impacts these mutations. We are currently drafting a manuscript detailing the results of our analysis. One undergraduate student (in addition to the two mentioned above) played a pivotal role in generating these data, and will be a coauthor on this manuscript. This work is broadly important for understanding the evolution and functional consequence of chromosomal inversions, and will form the basis for additional project on chromosomal inversions in D. melanogaster as well as other species.
